ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I am learning so much about how psychology studies are run and what topics are important. I am gaining insight into how COVID is impacting those with disabilities, and the connections between substance use and mental health stigma. I am also learning about how we construct narratives.
How to read/discuss literature in the field, study design and implementation, writing papers
Learned from listening to many different insightful presentations

I gained hands on experience of lab research, learnt about explaining study topics to people who are unfamiliar with the field, reporting results, coding using BORIS, and introductions to a wide range of topics relating to comparative cognition.
I learned the basics of Qualtrics, how to effectively communicate and engage in a research lab, and practiced the skill of independently programming/completing tasks.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No weaknesses. Just overall really great involvement with the lab. Plenty of opportunity to work and find areas of interest.
The course was very well designed and the weekly lab meetings helped me learn a lot.
Prof. Ahn is a fantastic PI, and the graduate students helped the group navigate some of the more complex intellectual intricacies of the project. Their roles in the semester proved to be a strength.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes-- work in Dr. Katie Wang's lab if you are interested in mental health stigma and disabilities!!
Yes, research is always a good experience no matter who you are.
Yes - if you find a lab you want to work in, this is a great way to do so.
Yes! It is great chance to start doing some research in a psych lab.
Yes! Everyone in the lab is very welcoming, there is a strong structure built to help us learn and gain experience, and the topics studied are very interesting.
